title: Gov't Slaps More Red Tape on Ride-Sharing Apps
text:
Ride-sharing apps like TADA will now have to obtain taxi licenses for each car they operate.

The curbs aim to close loopholes that have incensed established taxi drivers, who are pressuring the government to strangle the nascent ride-sharing industry in the crib.

Ride-sharing start-ups will not be able to operate with hire cars any more under new regulations released by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport on Wednesday.

"If these start-ups pay a portion of profits as a contribution for social cause, we will use it towards improving the welfare of taxi drivers and purchase of taxi licenses so that the new ride-sharing business and the existing taxi industry can coexist in a mutually beneficial way," Vice Transport Minister Kim Kyung-wook said.

The government will revise the relevant laws within this year and implement them in the first half of next year.

The revisions will stipulate that mobility platform services must obtain taxi license just like conventional taxi services, and all drivers they employ must have a taxi driver license.

The government wants to establish a separate body that will purchase taxi licenses and rent them out to start-ups. The industry expects that mobility platforms will need about 900 licenses a year, which will cost around W60 billion (US$1=W1,181).

Supposing the ride-sharing businesses pay an estimated W5 billion in license rental a year, the government needs to come up with the other W55 billion by itself. "We will be able to raise the funds by various means after finding out the demands of start-up businesses," the ministry said. It denied that the money will come from taxpayers but did not explain where it will find it.

The revised regulations do not specify whether it is legal to operate businesses with hire cars, which means it is effectively illegal. This is a big blow to TADA, which uses 1,000 hire vans to get around the current regulations.

"We considered allowing service based on hire cars, but protest from the taxi industry was so strong that we had to exclude it," Kim admitted.

Critics suspect that the government has its eyes firmly on conventional taxi drivers' votes in the upcoming general election. The government insisted that will not outlaw TADA immediately, so until the relevant laws are revised TADA exists in legal limbo.
